newsitem.title: FRANCE: EU's Kok hopeful on NATO-Russia ties.
newsitem.headline: EU's Kok hopeful on NATO-Russia ties.

text.p: Dutch Prime Minister Wim Kok expressed hope on Wednesday that Russia would soon ease its fierce opposition to NATO enlargement and accept a constructive relationship with the Atlantic alliance.

Kok said after meeting French President Jacques Chirac: "NATO enlargement should not lead to a worsening of relations with Russia, and I think having been in Moscow two days ago and having spoken with President (Boris) Yeltsin that we can be rather hopeful that it will be possible to come to positive steps in the months and perhaps even weeks ahead of us."

The Dutch leader, who visited Moscow on Monday in his capacity as current holder of the rotating European Union presidency, said it was essential that preparations for NATO to admit formerly communist east Euorpean countries go hand in hand with closer relations with Russia and Ukraine.
On Monday, he said Yeltsin had repeated Moscow's fierce opposition to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation's plans to admit former Soviet-bloc states.

"The Russian attitude has not changed (from opposing NATO expansion) but at the same time there is a strong will to reach a set of conclusions before Madrid," Kok, whose country also belongs to NATO, said then.
Russia regards NATO's eastward enlargement as a threat to its own security and is seeking a legally binding treaty with the alliance safeguarding its interests.
